I. THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY
A. Justification
1. The transaction technical assistance (TA) facility will cofinance feasibility and market
studies to support nonsovereign operations in the Pacific developing member countries (DMCs)
of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). ADB’s Private Sector Operations Department (PSOD)
has identified a pipeline of 10–15 projects for potential debt financing or equity investments in the
region. However, the projects require feasibility studies to assess and confirm they are viable
opportunities for PSOD. As project sponsors lack the immediate financial resources to prepare
the studies, the TA will cofinance feasibility studies alongside project sponsors, on a reimbursable
basis (para 5). The ensuing projects are in multiple sectors, in line with PSOD’s investment
priorities for the region (para 4), and all require similar support. The TA will also prepare market
studies to assess risks and opportunities in sectors that can potentially promote further private
sector growth in the region. The TA leverages the One ADB approach—drawing on resources
from ADB’s Pacific Department (PARD) to support deeper involvement of PSOD in the region.
2. Barriers to nonsovereign sector operations in the Pacific. All 14 of the Pacific DMCs
are small island developing states (SIDS), and seven of them are classified as fragile or conflict-
affected situations (FCAS).1 The cost of doing business in FCAS and SIDS is higher than normal,
the markets are small, and credit risks are high. Further, business environments in the Pacific
DMCs are underdeveloped, capacity shortages affect both the public and private sectors, and
there is a lack of infrastructure and services needed to support private sector growth. Additionally,
businesses are constrained by (i) limited access to regional and international markets, (ii) weak
implementation of business laws, and (iii) constrained access to financial services. Low risk-
adjusted returns often do not meet the requirements to be considered for ADB’s nonsovereign
operations or other private financing without a high level of development partner support. As a
result, ADB has not historically been able to identify opportunities to invest in private sector
initiatives in FCAS and SIDS, and the Pacific DMCs face exceptionally low levels of private sector
participation. Even pre-pandemic public expenditure was a relatively large part of the Pacific
economies,  averaging  58%  of  gross  domestic  product  across  the  12  small  Pacific  island
countries 2  economies.  Increasing  private  sector  participation,  including  through  ADB’s
nonsovereign operations, is essential to economic growth, infrastructure development, and the
sustainability of development impacts across the region.
3. ADB’s commitment to nonsovereign operations. In Strategy 2030, ADB makes a
number of commitments to FCAS and SIDS. These include prioritizing support for the poorest
and most vulnerable countries in the region, including FCAS and SIDS; augmenting resources to
accommodate  the  added  costs  of  identifying,  processing,  and  implementing  projects  and
investments in these countries; and pursuing development impacts as the key objective of its
private sector operations. Strategy 2030 states that “ADB will expand its private sector operations
in new and frontier markets, including challenging markets such as FCAS and SIDS. In the
process, ADB will consider smaller deal sizes with potentially higher risk and development
impacts, including inclusive business models.” Following the 13th replenishment of the Asian
1  ADB’s 14 Pacific DMCs comprise the Cook Islands, Fiji, Kiribati, the Marshall Islands (RMI), the Federated States of 
Micronesia (FSM), Nauru, Niue, Palau, Papua New Guinea, Samoa, Solomon Islands, Tonga, Tuvalu, and Vanuatu. 
The seven Pacific countries classified as FCAS are FSM, Kiribati, RMI, Nauru, Papua New Guinea, Solomon Islands 
and Tuvalu.  
2  The 12 small Pacific island countries comprise the Cook Islands, the FSM, Kiribati, the RMI, Nauru, Niue, Palau, 
Samoa, Solomon Islands, Tonga, Tuvalu, and Vanuatu. Niue is the newest ADB member, having joined in 2019.

2 
Development Fund (ADF-13), ADB established the private sector window (PSW) to address and 
reduce common financing constraints that hinder private sector transactions in group A countries. 
The PSW notes that “Upstream development work remains critical to unlocking PSO [private 
sector operations], particularly in challenging markets, and ADB will continue to allocate TA 
resources to group A countries, in particular FCAS and SIDS, for thematic areas that include 
private sector development.”3 The TA will focus on projects in the 14 Pacific DMCs, with a 
particular priority for a subset of the nine Group A countries, and on supporting projects in sectors 
that are aligned with both PSOD and PSW priorities.4 The TA will support PSOD in identifying 
bankable projects in the Pacific DMCs and building project readiness for PSW financing.  
4. The ensuing projects. In 2018, PSOD undertook a strategic review of nonsovereign
opportunities in the Pacific and identified four priority target sectors: (i) financial institutions and
trade finance, including commercial banks, microfinance, and insurance; (ii) renewable energy
generation; (iii) agribusiness, including a particular focus on fisheries, an important sector for
many Pacific DMCs; (iv) tourism and related infrastructure including hotels, which is an important
sector for many Pacific DMCs. The TA may also consider projects in the health and education
sectors because of their ability to provide catalytic support to socioeconomic development. The
target  sectors  are  aligned  with  priority  areas  identified  by  PSW,  which  include  tourism,
agribusiness and fisheries, and financial services that support lending to women and small- and
medium-sized enterprises. PARD and PSOD have since collaborated to establish a pipeline of
projects for nonsovereign lending in the target sectors. PARD has leveraged its field presence
through the Pacific country offices to identify opportunities, and PSOD has conducted preliminary
assessments and interviews and identified 10–15 potential projects. However, momentum will
stall if pipeline project sponsors do not have access to financial and technical support in preparing
feasibility  studies.  Further  assistance  is  also  required  to  assess  downstream  risks  and
opportunities in the target sectors. The TA will fund the preparation of professional feasibility
studies that enable ADB to act on near-term nonsovereign investment opportunities, while also
funding market studies to identify longer term opportunities aligned with PSOD and PSW priorities
for the region.
B. Outputs and Activities
5. Output 1: Feasibility studies prepared. The TA will cofinance up to 75% of the costs of
feasibility studies, alongside project sponsors. The percentage of TA contributions for each study
will vary based on the financial capacity of the project sponsors and the size of the potential
project. The feasibility studies will be for projects aligned with PSOD’s priority sectors for the
region, PSW priority areas, and with a focus on countries eligible for ADF-13 assistance (para 3).
PSOD will select the projects based on the quality and experience of the project sponsors, the
extent and positive conclusions of the initial pre-feasibility study work, and the likelihood of the
project’s long-term operational and financial success, and development impact. The TA will not
finance experimental projects or investments in unproven or undemonstrated technologies.5
Project sponsors will reimburse ADB’s TA-funded costs if the respective feasibility study is
positive, and the project sponsors are subsequently successful in raising the capital necessary to

Operations in Group A Countries (Supplementary Note). Manila.  
4  The nine group A countries in the Pacific are FSM, Kiribati, RMI, Nauru, Samoa, Solomon Islands, Tonga, Tuvalu,

3 
implement the project.6 The feasibility studies will be delivered to ADB and the project sponsors 
in digital format. The TA will prepare a minimum of three feasibility studies.  
6. Output 2: Market studies prepared. The TA will finance market studies by recognized
and reputable experts in subsectors that have growth potential and are aligned with PSOD and
PSW priorities. The market studies will support ADB and the private sector to assess risks and
opportunities in priority sectors, such as agribusiness, fisheries, and tourism. Whereas feasibility
studies under output 1 focus on individual projects with a comparably high degree of readiness,
market studies under output 2 will focus on evaluating markets that may present opportunities for
future individual developments. The market studies will be delivered to ADB in digital format. The
TA will prepare a minimum of three market studies.
C. Cost and Financing
7. The TA facility is estimated to cost $1,500,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by
ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund ($1,000,000 TASF-other sources and $500,000 TASF-
7). The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. The TA facility will be subject to
arrangements that will seek partial recovery of the amount financed under the TA facility. Activities
under output 1 will seek full recovery of the amount financed under the TA if the project’s sponsors
are able to raise the necessary capital to implement the ensuing project. Activities under output 2
are not subject to recovery as the market reports may benefit and be released to a number of
parties, including relevant government entities and all market participants. Project sponsors will
be informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project.
D. Implementation Arrangements
8. ADB will administer the TA, and disbursement of the TA resources will follow ADB’s
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2020, as amended from time to time). PARD and
PSOD will jointly administer the TA. The TA does not require logistical support from the DMCs.
Any necessary logistical support will be provided by the Pacific country offices. As TA resources
are repaid by project sponsors, ADB may consider replenishing the TA to allow it to finance
additional studies if and as appropriate. The TA duration will be 60 months, from December 2021
to November 2026.

10. Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated staff instructions.7 There is a very
limited number of appropriately qualified firms with relevant experience to conduct feasibility study
work in the Pacific DMCs, now compounded by limited access due to the coronavirus pandemic
(COVID-19). For this reason and due to the highly specialized nature of the assignments under
this TRTA, ADB will recruit consultants via any of the six methods of selection following discussion
with PPFD. Before seeking a proposal from the firms selected following DC, PARD’s Office of the
Director General will seek the approval of the Procurement, Portfolio and Financial Management
Department as mandated by the relevant Staff Instructions.
E. Governance
11. ADB will conduct integrity due diligence on project sponsors, the board of directors,
shareholders, and managers, to confirm in advance that they are not the subject of any unresolved
or substantiated adverse media or other relevant information that may pose significant integrity
risk.8 ADB’s review of these entities should also confirm that there is no cause to believe that
these have been established or are being used for money laundering or terrorism financing.
Project sponsors should have some record of developing similar projects as envisaged under the
TA.
